awd_abstract_narration: Mycorrhizae are specialized soil fungi that form symbiotic                      relationships with the roots of most woody plants.  The fungi are               important in the uptake of water and nutrients.  One group of                   mycorrhizal fungi are angiocarpic---that is, the fruiting body does             not open---and are commonly called truffle-like fungi.  From an                 ecological perspective, this is an especially important group of                organisms throughout the forests of the world, but they a                       relatively poorly known.  This is especially true for the forests               of the southern hemisphere.  A joint venture that involves                      scientists from the forestry programs of C.S.I.R.O. in Australia                and American mycologists from Oregon State University will conduct              extensive surveys of the Australasian rainforests for truffle-like              fungi.  It is certain that the collecting team will discover                    numerous new species, genera, and even families.  These forests are             being rapidly logged, thereby potentially eliminating many of the               endemic mycorrhizae before their ecological and economic utility                can be explored.  This research should make those materials                     available to the scientific community at large.
